Expectation1: Maintain passenger safety and provide assistance during service.
Situation1: A report has come in about a suspicious, unattended bag in one of the train cars.
Situation2: They quietly repeat a short mantra during their day without following the full ritual.
Story: As the subway rumbled through the tunnel, I kept my eyes on the monitors, alert for anything unusual. My shift had started before dawn, and I hadn’t had time for my full morning puja. Instead, I whispered the Gayatri mantra under my breath, hoping it would bring me some peace. Suddenly, a passenger reported an unattended bag in car three. My training as a subway operator kicked in—passenger safety was my top priority. I was supposed to stay focused, ready to make announcements, call security, and possibly evacuate the train. But as I reached for the intercom, I felt a pang of guilt. My mind was split: part of me wanted to pause, close my eyes, and finish my mantra for protection and clarity; the other part knew every second counted in a potential emergency. The weight of both roles pressed on me—my duty to the hundreds of people in my care, and my duty to my faith, which asked for calm and devotion even in chaos. My heart pounded as I hesitated, caught between the demands of the world outside and the world within.
